With the large amount of aid earmarked for Yemen aid to offset any famine (link), the UN seemly unlikely to announce or declare a famine given that a large amount of aid are flowing into the country without the need for a declaration of famine (the underlying main reason to declare a famine being to galvanize international aid and peacekeeping efforts).
US announces $165M in humanitarian aid to Yemen - Al Jazeera English https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/9/us-announces-165-million-humanitarian-aid-to-yemen Mon, 09 Aug 2021 16:46:47 GMT
https://www.wral.com/us-announces-more-aid-as-yemen-fighting-peace-efforts-stall/19818741/

My rationale is naive again. It is that famines are incredibly rare events, the UN would have to declare it, and there are multiple countries in contention to be the next famine stricken country, which divides the chances among them (though that could also mean that one of them is destined to have the designation and Yemen is contender #1). Probabilistically, however, I don't think so. What backs up my confidence to remain low is the forecast provided by other users that show an improvement over the next few months.

No priors or domain knowledge. Averaging the last two forecasts.

The UN has declared famines in 2 counties in the last decade. In South Sudan in 2017, over 32% of the population was in Phase 3 or above, compared to the most recent report of 25% in Yemen. South Sudan had similar issues with conflict, but currently there is also the coronavirus pandemic. Given the infrequency of these conditions being met, I imagine a low base rate, which I am adjusting upward due to the incentive toward action as richer countries start recovering from the coronavirus pandemic.

I think they have had famine for a while, the UN just haven't been able to get the personnel in there to actually record and diagnose it. And I don't see that changing. Apparently Britain is the quill holder in the United Nations, meaning that any UN declaration on this issue has to be initiated by Britain and I think they have become rather hands off on the situation.
Some people imagine they are evil. Some people don’t have to imagine. Some people imagine they are good, and they are the worst.

Dropping forecast down a little closer to the 'crowd', for now. https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen/food-security-outlook/february-2021

Yet another perspective: 7/30 past years had a famine. Say this year is gonna be 8th. 8/31 years with a famine, or 26%. Multiply .26 by remaining time of year, you get 20. Maybe divide by 4 because Yemen could be any of the four countries on the brink of famine. However, with so much time remaining, let us use 20.

Although the current Suez blockage could delay humanitarian aid and make things worse in the hardest hit area of Hajjah and Amran for a brief period of time, I don't see it hitting famine level and FEWSNET projects improvement in this region to Crisis phase 3 in the coming months. There was a relaxation in the fuel blockade last week, although this may only be temporary, it is a good sign and even a brief end to the blockage could delay crisis hitting famine levels through 2021.

But let's say 6% is too low. Let's say instead of a 1/17 chance it's doubly more likely, at 1/8. Now it's about 12%. Another set of alternative numbers produces about 10%. Thus I will nestle in-between, at 11%.

Approx 7 years in last 30 years had at least one famine declared. 4 countries are on the brink of famine in 2021. Factor in that Phase 5 is relatively rare. Factor in time passing. Maybe factor in uncertainty of model. I would forecast 1% but I'm gonna stick to 6%.

Based on current and project Integrated Food Security Phase Classifications, the metric for UN's declaration of famine. 45-50% of pop. are rated at 3 or higher (1-5 scale) in current and projected food insecurity assessments. However, bulk of population currently experiencing 2 (Stressed) to 3 (Crisis) phases of food insecurity. 0% are at IPC Phase 5, a famine. Forecast may shift if greater % of pop. start to move toward higher IPC phases.
Reducing forecast due to US pressure on Saudi Arabia to end conflict.
Drop due to ceasefire deal, which may promote more humanitarian aid.
Reducing due to possibility of peace deal.

The following link is comprehensive enough for me to drop back down to baseline. The UN's weekly newsletter does not mention Yemen this week. I only recall it being mentioned once or twice since January? I have also made a fire forecast on this site that is lower than the crowd's, so maybe there is a link.

By end of year at current rate according to the model I linked to, the potential famine situation will only be about 60–80% complete in terms of getting to 20% of the population and in terms of chronological time to get to 20%. If this growth were exponential, it would reach 20% by October ish but 70–80% of the remaining time till 2022 would have already elapsed.
Given the base rate and the acute situation already facing the country, poor results at fundraising, I am unfortunately more confident than the consensus that there will be a famine declared.

This is a very disturbing map https://hungermap.wfp.org/?_ga=2.192297770.1452894778.1615971541-3064242.1615971541 The UN has high levels of food hunger reported in Yemen and we have another summer to go through. Given we are furthest away from a harvest then things are only likely to get worse. Especially as aid is going to be scares this year https://news.un.org/en/story/2017/03/553212-yemen-brink-famine-warns-un-food-relief-agency-chief-appealing-resources-and
Per usual, calling a famine by an international body is low probability.

I am more confident than the crowd since the current situation and projection until mid-year* (and looming summer season) have increased my confidence that one will be declared in ANY part of Yemen -- different story if it was for the entire country. My understanding is that 20% of a region has to be in Phase 5 "famine" to be declared a famine, and the UN needs to recognize this finding. Please correct this information if needed.
USAID has just resumed which would lower the odds.

"..Although not the most likely scenario, Famine (IPC Phase 5) would be possible if food supply is cut off for a prolonged period of time." Source: https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen/key-message-update/january-2021

Major food insecurity will lead to famine yet will it meet the question criteria as far as the time goes. Phase 3 IPC ==16 districts and a total133 district’s are in a food crisis And with the blockade of Yemen the UN will be involved https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockade_of_Yemen#:~:text=The%20blockade%20of%20Yemen%20refers%20to%20a%20sea%2C,United%20States%20joined%20the%20blockade%20in%20October%202016.

Yemen is already experiencing a famine by most of the UN's measures. The UN's technical definition of famine (see first source) is "A famine declaration requires evidence of crude death rates higher than two per 10,000 people per day, a global acute malnutrition rate greater than 30 percent, and an extreme lack of food affecting more than 20 percent of the population."

The United Nations is projecting that famine will hit Yemen this year. They needed $3.85 billion in aid to prevent famine, and only $1.7 billion was pledged. It's possible that due to the current economic trouble caused by covid the countries involved may not even make good on those pledges. the United States has stated that it would stop its aid for the Saudi Arabia coalition that is attacking civilian targets such as grain silos and water treatment plants and cranes that unload ships at the harbor and cattle, but so far the United States is still assisting Saudi Arabia with intelligence and airplane parts and other assistance. https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/801280-famine-in-yemen

Recent UN fundraising only raised half of what they said they needed to prevent famine. UK cut its aid by 1/2. Saudi blockade is still in effect. Obviously the articles are written to try to drum up aid, but that doesn't make the reporting inaccurate. All it takes is one province to be given famine status.

The Houthis' rebels most important battle for invasion and control of the Marib governorate could fail, which (alongside the Biden administration's end of a one-sided support for the KSA) increases the likelihood of an end to war and fights. "A stalemate may be the best-case scenario for now. The IRG can claim to have fought off the Houthis and saved the city, which is as important for the IRG as it is for Yemen as a whole. Marib city is one of the places in Yemen that point toward a viable future. The IRG, local government, and tribal elites have worked together to build and re-build functioning state and local institutions from the ground up." https://jamestown.org/program/yemens-fate-hinges-on-the-battle-for-marib/

"Sweden and Switzerland are set to host a donor conference, where countries are to be urged to contribute to funds for poorer nations; United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is set to appeal for $3.85 billion in relief aid for Yemen." https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/yemen-could-be-heading-towards-mass-famine/funding/slideshow/81268727.cms
i thought famine would be the next clarion call of disaster but it looks like real Bird Flu is going to suffice for fear mongers.

The situation is not going to improve until Saudi Arabia lifts their blockades. the biggest reason why a famine might not be declared is because the United Nations can't get access to make an evaluation.
Reducing forecast due to delisting of rebels as a terrorist organisation.
More importantly will NATO support a UN decision secondary to Saudi’s Arabia calling a cease of action.

There have been famines declared in 1984 (Ethiopia), 1991 (Somalia), 1996 (North Korea), 2000 (Ethiopia), 2008 (Sudan) and 2011 (Somalia) and 2017 (South Sudan). https://news.un.org/en/story/2011/07/382072-un-declares-famine-two-regions-southern-somalia https://news.un.org/en/story/2017/02/551812-famine-declared-region-south-sudan-un

Decreasing following the Houthis being delisted as a terrorist organization and the US no longer providing arms to Saudi Arabia for the war. Both of these will help humanitarian aid organizations get food to people making a declaration of famine less likely.

I actually think this could reasonably sit at 49% in light of potentially resolving on a technicality, for all intents and purposes, Yemen is already experiencing a famine. The designation has lagged the better half of a year. That said, it appears aid will be administered unhindered going forward and official designation may never come. With two months until the lean season, my thought is that international efforts have time to mobilize. We'll need to review Apr-Jun and then after that a dramatic decline in likelihood.

I'm reducing my forecast somewhat due to Biden's recent announcement that he is "ending" the US involvement in the war in Yemen. however, they have not yet announced whether they are going to reverse the ruling that the houthis are terrorists. this seems to me a situation where Biden says one thing to the US public and says a different thing to Saudi Arabia. he declares his involvement in the war over to the United states, and then to Saudi Arabia he appeases them by keeping the terrorist designation in place. if they were going to revoke the designation, why haven't they already done so? There is nothing to "review".
Reducing my estimate due to Blinken's review of terrorist designation.
the United Nations states that 50,000 people are already in famine in the country, it's just that no specific region on that map has turned to level 5 yet.
the United Nations states that 50,000 people are already in famine in the country, it's just that no specific region on that map has turned to level 5 yet.

IPC only permits classification of Famine when all regular IPC protocols and special Famine protocols are met. The special protocols are: 1.) Requirement of reliable evidence on the three outcomes (Food Consumption or Livelihood Change, Global Acute Malnutrition and Crude Death Rate), all of which are either currently or projected to be above Famine Thresholds (>20% of households with extreme food gaps, >30% of children acutely malnourished, and CDR> 2/10,000/day). 2.) Undergoing a Famine Review Process to validate the classification. 3.) Development of IPC Famine Alert adhering to pre-determined standards.

Decreasing my forecast slightly because while there is a severe food problem in Yemen, the bar for the UN to declare a famine exists is high. This is a technical process that does not occur frequently and the UN has been criticized in the past for taking so long to declare a famine. Additionally, the Biden administration froze most of the sanctions on the Houthis to allow for humanitarian aid and is currently reviewing the foreign terrorist organization designation. I think this designation will be revoked and humanitarian aid organizations will be able to supply just enough food for the UN to not declare a famine.

"Famine seems to be the hardest word—an outcome no one working to end hunger wants, not least Margot van der Velden, Head of Emergencies at the World Food Programme (WFP).[...] and it’s why WFP is calling for US$5 billion to set up a rapid-response fund and do its utmost to make sure famine does not happen." https://www.wfp.org/stories/hunger-hotspots-2021-world-food-programme-united-nations-famine-food-aid https://www.wfp.org/emergencies/yemen-emergency

The ongoing crisis in Yemen is only continuing. As new policies put more pressure on the belligerents, fighting is likely to intensify and exacerbate food insecurity. There are few effective actions currently being taken to avoid this outcome.
Updating due to commercial suppliers leaving Yemen and ongoing pandemic effects.
La pandemia COVID19 ha limitado la economía global afectando principalmente a las economías de países con altos índices de pobreza. Yemen tuvo una alerta de hambruna en el tercer trimestre de 2020.
Pres Biden will attempt to show leadership and compassion for mitigating conflict. Influencing UN and neighboring countries!
The need is real, but the UN might be waiting for a new US position on Yeman
Political pressures from Saudi Arabia, in addition to reasons listed by others
Ineffective distribution and desire of new admin to address this issue
The criteria to declare a famine is surprisingly restrictive. One hasn't been declared (that I can see) since 2017 in South Sedan. (https://news.un.org/en/story/2020/11/1077872)
"Not the most likely scenario" based on professional projections...

16 districts of Yemen are in Emergency (IPC Phase 4). Phase 5 is famine. Different humanitarian agencies and international NGOs have stated that it is increasingly difficult to bring food to the conflict zones and that there are not enough financial resources to attend the populations in need of food (80% of the population subsists through humanitarian assistance).
What is a famine?

Stark assessment: [Without continued aid, etc..:] "..We're on the verge...""..of the worst catastrophe we've seen, even beyond Ethiopia..." per this source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e1JyYSUD6Ac

Near Biden Admin is most certainly going to label the Houthi's as a terrorist group based on their last 10 years. That will cut off aid to many of the already Yemeni's who are already insecure. Most of Yemen is likely to experience famine in 2021.

Yemen has had an on-going famine since 2016. The UN declared that the possibility of famine existed in Yemen in October 2018. The stalling of peace efforts between the different parties in the Yemeni civil war and the scaling back of famine relief efforts by the UN due to a lack of funding and the COVID-19 pandemic together mean that the situation in Yemen is unlikely to improve and will most likely get worse. High propensity for a famine to exist and the lack of UN funding increases the likelihood that the UN will use a famine declaration as a rallying cry to galvanize support for relief efforts.

The report says "the caseload in Catastrophe (IPC Phase 5) is mainly found in [the governorates of] Al Jawf, Hajjah and Amra", and that these people who are in Catastrophe are found in the districts of Kharab Al Marashi, Rajuzah, As Sawd, As Sudah, and Qarah.

The trend across the country over the last 6 months is for the situation to be worsening. 12 areas are currently level 4 and many areas have changed from level 2 to level 3. all it takes is for one area to go to level 5 for this question to resolve yes there is a full 1/3 of the country that can't even be cataloged because the fighting is so bad. It is likely there is already famine in one of those areas. Considering we have an entire year for this question and only need a single area to go to level 5 to resolve yes, this seems almost certain.
It’s a bit more complicated. Food is a national security issue everywhere. Let’s ask a different question. Will the people in Yemen decide on an acidic or alkaline diet?
Because there is famine already there and with most of the world looking to solve other pressing problems, Yemen will face this horrible ordeal.

From what I can gather, according to the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification, developed by the UN: a famine requires: "At least 20 percent of households face a complete lack of food and/or other basic needs and starvation, death, and destitution are evident; and acute malnutrition prevalence exceeds 30%; and mortality rates exceed 2/10000/day". This level of humanitarian crisis corresponds to IPC phase 5.
Famine it Yemen has been ongoing for years now. I think the UN will see more U.S. international involvement, and could look to the U.S. as a supporter of a declared famine in order to gain support.

1) Recent UN announcement was to lobby against Trump/Pompeo categorization of Houthis as a terrorist org, which will restrict potential for food aid. 2) Declaration likely whether or not policy is changed.W/o change famine may occur. With change, declaration will get AID orgs involved without fear of US reaction.
Saudis will accelerate war before Biden works to end war
On recent form, it seems that declaring a famine depends on more than just a whole lot of hungry people. Yemen has plenty of those and will doubtless have more. Stay tuned.

US terror designation seems to have very little impact in my view because I don't think the Houthis have enough influence and resources to avert a famine. I am afraid the upcoming spring and summer seasons will cause more harm than good. Portions of Yemen seem to be close to the threshold of famine. The trend since April 2020 is getting worse. The climatological average for rain, wind, and temperature for the next week show times of below average rain, wind, and higher than average temperatures (though by not that much; it doesn't improve, either).
Starting here, but I'm hopeful. I have to refresh my memory on their regional lean season: https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen

Mike Pompeo’s designation of Houthis as foreign terror group blocks food and other aid. He is convinced that the Houthis are directed by Iran. I believe the Biden administration will revisit the terrorist label for the Houthis sooner rather than later which could pave the way for relief. However, A December 30 guided missile attack thought to be perpetrated by Houthis casts some doubt over hope for a change in designation.
Biden stated that Trump's policy on Yemen ends now. Trump's last (out the door) policy on Houthis will likely be reversed. I believe he's serious and will move quickly.
